facts.text: Karnail Singh and Malkiat Singh appealed by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Punjab confirming their conviction by the Additional Sessions Judge of Ferozepore under section 302 IPC and death sentence.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave by Karnail Singh and Malkiat Singh against the judgment of the High Court of Punjab confirming their conviction by the Additional Sessions Judge of Ferozepore under section 302, Indian Penal Code, and the sentence of death passed on them.

facts.text: There had been long standing enmity between the appellants and their party and the deceased Gurbaksh Singh and his party, resulting in a number of crimes and court proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The facts as found by the courts below are as follows There had been long standing enmity between the appellants and their party on the one hand and the deceased Gurbaksh Singh and his party on the other, resulting in a number of crimes, and proceedings in court.

facts.text: On 27th January 1952 at about sunset time, Gurbaksh Singh was sitting inside his house and his sister Mst. Bholan was in the kitchen.

anchor.surface_text: On the 27th January, 1952, at about sunset time, Gurbaksh Singh was sitting inside his house on the sabbath and his sister Mst. Bholan was in the kitchen.

facts.text: The appellants and their men came to the place armed with rifles, got on the roof of the house of Gurbaksh Singh and challenged him to come out.

anchor.surface_text: Then the appellants and their men came to the place armed with rifles, got on the roof of the house of Gurbaksh Singh and challenged him to come out.

facts.text: Gurbaksh Singh and Mst. Bholan went to the kotha and bolted the door from inside.

anchor.surface_text: Gurbaksh Singh and Mst. Bholan went to the kotha and bolted the door from inside.

facts.text: The appellants and their men made holes in the roof with spades, ignited inflammable materials such as dry twigs, threw them inside the kotha through the holes and set fire to the building.

anchor.surface_text: Then the appellants and their men made holes in the roof with spades, ignited inflammable materials, such as dry twigs, and threw them inside the kotha through the holes and set fire to the building.

facts.text: Gurbaksh Singh and Mst. Bholan were caught inside and burnt to death.

anchor.surface_text: Both Gurbaksh Singh and Mst. Bholan were caught inside and burnt to death.

facts.text: A brother of Gurbaksh Singh called Dev was away at the time, seized when he turned up, thrown into the flames and burnt to death according to prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: A brother of Gurbaksh Singh called Dev, who had been at that time away, was, according to the prosecution, seized when he subsequently turned up, thrown into the flames and was also burnt to death.

facts.text: Gurnam Singh PW13, cousin and neighbour of Gurbaksh Singh, slipped out of the village and reported the occurrence at police station Nihal Singhwala eight miles away vide Exhibit PQ at 10.30 PM.

anchor.surface_text: Meantime one Gurnam Singh, P.W. 13, a cousin of Gurbaksh Singh and his neighbour, managed to slip out of the village and reported the occurrence at the police station at Nihal Singhwala, a place eight miles away vide Exhibit PQ . It was then 10.30 P.M.

facts.text: Police sub-inspector PW25 went to the village with constables and Gurnam Singh, found the house mostly burnt, recovered charred remains of three dead bodies identified as Gurbaksh, Dev and Mst. Bholan.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this information, the police sub-inspector, P.W. 25, went to the village with a posse of constables and with Gurnam Singh. He found the house mostly burnt and recovered therefrom the charred remains of three dead bodies and they were identified as those of Gurbaksh, Dev and Mst. Bholan.

facts.text: Appellant Karnail Singh was seen at the place and arrested on the spot.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Karnail Singh was actually seen at that place and arrested on the spot.

facts.text: Malkiat Singh mentioned in Exhibit PQ, found in his house with gunshot wounds and arrested.

anchor.surface_text: Malkiat Singh who had been mentioned in Exhibit PQ as one of the participants was found in his house with gunshot wounds and was also arrested.

facts.text: Eight persons including appellants charged under section 148 IPC for unlawful assembly to burn house of Gurbaksh Singh and murder him, Dev and Mst. Bholan, and under 302/149 for murder.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually eight persons, including the appellants, were charged under section 148, Indian Penal Code, for forming an unlawful assembly with the object of burning the house of Gurbaksh Singh and murdering him, Dev and Mst. Bholan, and under section 302 read with section 149 for their murder.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge Ferozepore acquitted two accused, convicted six others including appellants under 148 and 302/149, sentenced to death.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Sessions Judge, Ferozepore, held that the case had not been established beyond doubt as against two of the accused and he accordingly acquitted them. He convicted the six others including the appellants under section 148 and section 302 read with section 149 and sentenced them to death.

facts.text: Punjab High Court on appeal acquitted four accused other than appellants due to insufficient evidence, confirmed conviction and sentences of appellants, set aside 149 and substituted section 34.

anchor.surface_text: As four of the accused were acquitted in appeal, the learned Judges set aside the conviction of the appellants under section 149 and substituted section 34, Indian Penal Code, therefore.

facts.text: Karnail Singh found emerging out of the burning house with a spear in hand, injuries on person, blood-stained pyjama, seized as Exhibits P-12 and P-20.

anchor.surface_text: As regards Karnail Singh, the police sub-inspector, P.W. 25, actually found him emerging out of the burning house with a spear in his hand. He had injuries on his person and his pyjama was blood-stained. He was arrested on the spot and the spear and the pyjama were seized and marked as Exhibits P-12 and P-20.

facts.text: Malkiat Singh had gunshot wounds when arrested.

anchor.surface_text: As for Malkiat Singh, his name was mentioned in the first information report, Exhibit PQ, and P.W. 25 went to his house and found him with gunshot wounds and arrested him.

facts.text: In statement under section 342 CrPC, Karnail Singh stated he saw house on fire, went there, assaulted by culprits, Malkiat came to help, received gunshot, went home.

anchor.surface_text: In the statement given by Karnail Singh under section 342, Criminal Procedure Code, he stated that when he saw the house of Gurnam Singh on fire, he went there and was assaulted by culprits, that Malkiat Singh came there to help him, that when they were grappling with the culprits he was attacked and Malkiat Singh received a gunshot and thereafter they went away to their houses.

facts.text: PW14 deposed that Malkiat Singh stated he had been shot by one of his own men and then left.

anchor.surface_text: This view is supported by the evidence of P.W. 14 who deposed that while the incidents were in progress Malkiat Singh stated that he had been shot be one of his own men and then left the place.

facts.text: No gun was recovered from the house of the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: and to the fact that no gun was recovered from the house, and that there was accordingly nothing to connect Malkiat Singh with the incident at the house of Gurbaksh Singh.

anchor.surface_text: set aside the conviction of the appellants under section 149 and substituted section 34, Indian Penal Code, therefore. Two contentions have been urged on behalf of the appellants, that the evidence which had been accepted by the learned Judges as reliable was insufficient to establish the guilt of the appellants and that their conviction under section 34 was bad as no charge had been framed against them under that section.

But if the facts to be proved and the evidence to be adduced with reference to the charge under section 149 would be the same if the charge were under section 34, then the failure to charge

arguments.claim: On the facts of this case there can be no difference between the object and the intention with which the offenses were committed

holdings.text: The corroboration that is required in such cases is not what would be necessary to support the evidence of an approver but what would be sufficient to lend assurance to the evidence before them, and satisfy them that the particular persons were really concerned in the murder of the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: The corroboration that is required in such cases is not what would be necessary to support the evidence of an approver but what would be sufficient to lend assurance to the evidence before them, and satisfy them that the particular persons were really concerned in the murder of the deceased.  Vide Lachhman Singh v. State  1952 S.C.R. 839 at p. 845. . Karnail Singh was arrested on the spot with a spear and a bloodstained pyjama, and these are pieces of evidence which would support the inference that he was concerned in the crime.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partisan relative witness needs only assurance of involvement via circumstances, not approver-level corroboration; cites Lachhman Singh.

holdings.text: So far as Karnail Singh is concerned, his presence at the scene of occurrence under the circumstances disclosed in the evidence is sufficient to corroborate the evidence of P.W. 13.

anchor.surface_text: So far as Karnail Singh is concerned, his presence at the scene of occurrence under the circumstances disclosed in the evidence is sufficient to corroborate the evidence of P.W. 13. It should be remembered that Gurnam Singh is not an approver. He is a witness against whom the learned Judges had nothing to say and if they required corroboration of his evidence it was because he was a relation of the deceased and it was considered not safe to base a conviction on his sole testimony.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Emerging from burning house with spear, injuries, blood-stained clothes in context of enmity and no other explanation supports participation.

holdings.text: where it consists of distinct and separate matters, there is no reason why an admission contained in one matter should not be relied on without reference to the statements relating to other matters.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the statement of the accused under section 342, Criminal Procedure Code, it is true that if it is sought to be used as an admission it must be read as a whole but where it consists of distinct and separate matters, there is no reason why an admission contained in one matter should not be relied on without reference to the statements relating to other matters. In this case the admission of the appellant that he was present at or near the scene of occurrence is distinct and separate from his explanation as to how he received the injuries.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presence admission distinct from exculpatory injury explanation; reject false story of unknown culprits, accept presence as admission.

holdings.text: Thus there are ample materials for holding that the gunshot wounds were received by Malkiat Singh in the house of Gurbaksh Singh and that is sufficient corroboration of the evidence of P.W. 13.

anchor.surface_text: Thus there are ample materials for holding that the gunshot wounds were received by Malkiat Singh in the house of Gurbaksh Singh and that is sufficient corroboration of the evidence of P.W. 13. In this view we must overrule the first contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Name in FIR, PW14 testimony of self-statement 'shot by own man', presence admission, no other incident; rules out firing from inside due to medical/no gun.

holdings.text: In this view we must overrule the first contention.

anchor.surface_text: Thus there are ample materials for holding that the gunshot wounds were received by Malkiat Singh in the house of Gurbaksh Singh and that is sufficient corroboration of the evidence of P.W. 13. In this view we must overrule the first contention. Then the next question is whether the conviction of the appellant under section 302 read with section 34, when they had been charged only under section 302 read with section 149, was illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed per-appellant corroboration of sole reliable eyewitness PW13 via circumstances, presence, injuries, partial admissions satisfies assurance standard.

holdings.text: But if the facts to be proved and the evidence to be adduced with reference to the charge under section 149 would be the same if the charge were under section 34, then the failure to charge the accused under section 34 could not result in any prejudice and in such cases the substitution of section 34 for section 149 must be held to be a formal matter.

anchor.surface_text: If the common object which is the subject-matter of the charge under section 149 does not necessarily involve a common intention, then the substitution of section 34 for section 149 might result in prejudice to the accused and ought not therefore to be permitted. But if the facts to be proved and the evidence to be adduced with reference to the charge under section 149 would be the same if the charge were under section 34, then the failure to charge the accused under section 34 could not result in any prejudice and in such cases the substitution of section 34 for section 149 must be held to be a formal matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections differ but overlap per Barendra Kumar; substitution allowed if no prejudice i.e. same facts/evidence prove both; cites Lachhman upholding similar.

holdings.text: On the facts of this case there can be no difference between the object and the intention with which the offenses were committed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Long enmity, appellants on roof making holes, setting fire with victims trapped inside; burning house to kill equates common object to common intention.

h1 defines required corroboration as sufficient to lend assurance, addressing i4 on sufficient corroboration for PW13 evidence against appellants

anchor.surface_text: The corroboration that is required in such cases is not what would be necessary to support the evidence of an approver but what would be sufficient to lend assurance to the evidence before them, and satisfy them that the particular persons were really concerned in the murder of the deceased.  Vide Lachhman Singh v. State  1952 S.C.R. 839 at p. 845. . Karnail Singh was arrested on the spot with a spear and a bloodstained pyjama, and these are pieces of evidence which would support the inference that he was concerned in the crime.

Thus there are ample materials for holding that the gunshot wounds were received by Malkiat Singh in the house of Gurbaksh Singh and that is sufficient corroboration of the evidence of P.W. 13. In this view we must overrule the first contention. Then the next question is whether the conviction of the appellant under section 302 read with section 34, when they had been charged only under section 302 read with section 149, was illegal. The contention of the appellants is that the scope of section 149 is different from that of section 34 [...] On the facts of this case there can be numberdifference between the object and the intention with which the offenses were companymitted.

anchor.surface_text: So far as Karnail Singh is concerned, his presence at the scene of occurrence under the circumstances disclosed in the evidence is sufficient to corroborate the evidence of P.W. 13. It should be remembered that Gurnam Singh is not an approver. He is a witness against whom the learned Judges had nothing to say and if they required corroboration of his evidence it was because he was a relation of the deceased and it was considered not safe to base a conviction on his sole testimony.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the statement of the accused under section 342, Criminal Procedure Code, it is true that if it is sought to be used as an admission it must be read as a whole but where it consists of distinct and separate matters, there is no reason why an admission contained in one matter should not be relied on without reference to the statements relating to other matters. In this case the admission of the appellant that he was present at or near the scene of occurrence is distinct and separate from his explanation as to how he received the injuries.

Thus there are ample materials for holding that the gunshot wounds were received by Malkiat Singh in the house of Gurbaksh Singh and that is sufficient corroboration of the evidence of P.W. 13. In this view we must overrule the first contention. Then the next question is whether the conviction of the appellant under section 302 read with section 34, when they had been charged only under section 302 read with section 149, was illegal. The contention of the appellants is that the scope of section 149 is different from that of section 34 [...] On the facts of this case there can be numberdifference between the object and the intention with which the offenses were companymitted.

edges.explanation: h3 qualifies p1's general rule of taking s342 whole by holding that distinct matters allow separate use of admission, distinguishing based on separateness

anchor.surface_text: ecourse to section 34 when the charge is only under section 149. Whether such recourse can be had or number must depend on the facts of each case. Thi

anchor.surface_text: If the common object which is the subject-matter of the charge under section 149 does not necessarily involve a common intention, then the substitution of section 34 for section 149 might result in prejudice to the accused and ought not therefore to be permitted. But if the facts to be proved and the evidence to be adduced with reference to the charge under section 149 would be the same if the charge were under section 34, then the failure to charge the accused under section 34 could not result in any prejudice and in such cases the substitution of section 34 for section 149 must be held to be a formal matter.
